## Overview

This archive contains **65+ original historical documents** spanning from 1854 to 1915, meticulously preserved and digitized from The Rittenhouse Residence collection. Each document has been verified through Philadelphia city records, newspaper archives, and historical societies.

<div class="deed-collection">
<h2>Complete Chain of Title</h2>
<p>17 property deeds documenting every transfer of 1822 Pine Street from its construction in 1854 through present day. These legal documents establish the unbroken provenance of one of Rittenhouse Square's most significant historic properties.</p>
</div>

---

### Major Historical Events

::: {.timeline-document}
<img src="images/documents/Thu_Apr_23_1891_Page_3_Scarlet_Fever_web.jpg" alt="1891 Philadelphia newspaper reporting scarlet fever death">
<div class="timeline-content">
<h3><span class="document-year">1891</span> The Spencer Family Tragedy</h3>
<p><strong>Philadelphia Inquirer - November 28, 1891</strong></p>
<p>Heartbreaking coverage of 7-year-old Howard Spencer Jr.'s death from scarlet fever at 1822 Pine Street. This tragedy would profoundly impact the Spencer family and lead to Agnes Spencer's transformative renovation eight years later.</p>
<p class="document-description">This document provides crucial context for understanding the emotional significance of the 1899 renovation.</p>
<a href="../raw_documents/The_Philadelphia_Inquirer_1891_11_28_Page_2.pdf" class="view-document-btn">Read Full Article</a>
</div>
:::

::: {.timeline-document}
<img src="images/documents/1899_renovation_web.jpg" alt="1899 Duhring Okie Ziegler renovation announcement">
<div class="timeline-content">
<h3><span class="document-year">1899</span> Architectural Transformation</h3>
<p><strong>Philadelphia Times - August 6, 1899</strong></p>
<p>Announcement of Agnes Spencer's commission of prestigious architects Duhring, Okie & Ziegler for a complete modernization. This renovation created the elegant spaces visitors experience today, including the grand parlors and refined architectural details.</p>
<p class="document-description">The firm's other works include the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel and numerous Rittenhouse Square mansions.</p>
<a href="../raw_documents/The_Philadelphia_Times_1899_08_06_Page_10.pdf" class="view-document-btn">Read Full Article</a>
</div>
:::

::: {.timeline-document}
<img src="images/documents/1901_wedding_web.jpg" alt="1901 Rolin-Plumb society wedding announcement">
<div class="timeline-content">
<h3><span class="document-year">1901</span> High Society Wedding</h3>
<p><strong>Philadelphia Inquirer - October 27, 1901</strong></p>
<p>Elaborate society page coverage of the Rolin-Plumb wedding reception held at 1822 Pine Street. The article details the guest list, floral arrangements, and menu, providing a window into Edwardian high society entertainment.</p>
<p class="document-description">This event exemplified the property's role as a premier venue for Philadelphia's social elite.</p>
<a href="../raw_documents/The_Philadelphia_Inquirer_1901_10_27_Page_19.pdf" class="view-document-btn">Read Full Article</a>
</div>
:::

::: {.timeline-document}
<img src="images/documents/1915_suffrage_web.jpg" alt="1915 Equal Franchise Society ticket sales announcement">
<div class="timeline-content">
<h3><span class="document-year">1915</span> Suffragette Headquarters</h3>
<p><strong>Evening Public Ledger - January 8, 1915</strong></p>
<p>Notice that Miss Martha Davis is selling Equal Franchise Society tickets from 1822 Pine Street, documenting the property's role in the women's suffrage movement. The house served as an organizing location for this pivotal civil rights campaign.</p>
<p class="document-description">This places 1822 Pine at the center of Philadelphia's contribution to women's voting rights.</p>
<a href="../raw_documents/Evening_Public_Ledger_1915_01_08_Page_10.pdf" class="view-document-btn">Read Full Article</a>
</div>
:::
